awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: RUI: An Exploratory Study of Technology Adoption in K-12: Educational Benefits vs Privacy Costs
awd_abstract_narration:
This project explores technology adoption practices and interactions and the digital data literacy of education technology adoption decision makers in California K-12 public school districts. Data profiles constructed from the comingling of data from many sources (school, home, mobile technology) can follow the individual through his or her lifetime. Although there is an increasing understanding in education about digital literacy, there is a general lack of understanding about digital data literacy, or the ease and potential of comingling of data exchanged online, despite its purpose or use. Current regulations such as the Familly Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA) may provide inadequate protections for future inference or predictive uses. The goal of this project is to explore the extent to which school technology decision-makers consider youth privacy and the long-term use and dissemination of children's digital information.

Using a sample of California school districts, this project investigates educational technology procurement strategies and processes. Research methods include in-depth interviews and a preliminary survey to examine the digital data literacy of educational technology decision makers in K-12, and whether, how, issues of youth and family privacy are addressed by education technology adoption decision makers. The project will also involve a formal review of privacy literature involving several relevant disciplines and investigations of the marketing processes involved in educational technology procurement. Understanding the complexity and impact of educational technology adoption is essential. This project advances the discussion of privacy across commercial, public policy, and education interests. Students will be involved in all phases of the research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Educational settings worldwide have a significant impact on the early use of devices and online media by children. Educational technology adoption decisions by K-12 schools may lead to long term repercussions for students and society. In this research we explore whether and how California (CA) schools and educators make technology decisions on behalf of their students, with a focus on the ways in which privacy and data security are considered in technology adoption and use decisions. 

K-12 Technology Use Challenges:

  • Educational settings (compulsory) significantly impact children?s early use of devices and online media.
  • Student privacy protection is a key part of children?s digital well-being. 
  • Digital literacy is taught in schools, but digital data literacy is lacking. 
  • Digital data literacy is an understanding and knowledge of privacy risks with technology use and personal information exchanges, based on Ng (2012) Digital Literacy Model and building on ?technical literacy? [1].
  • Technology use at an early age increases privacy and security risks with student digital data (aggregated and personal). 
  • Family and teacher information are also exchanged when K-12 students use EdTech.

Based on interviews with CA K-12 school districts and analysis of state reports, we conclude that privacy related issues vary in school districts for information technology (IT) decisions and actions, versus educational technology (EdTech) decisions and actions. While IT is more about the adoption and use of technology through devices (hardware, infrastructures, etc.), EdTech is focused on the application of technology for the purpose of learning. As a result, the risk levels and issues also differ, creating what we term a privacy/security chasm with unique privacy challenges for information technology and educational technology. 

Key Findings: 

  • Private corporations (i.e. Alphabet, McGraw Hill, Oracle, Adobe, Microsoft, etc.) provide educational technology and collect/store/exchange student data with partners, affiliates, and the like.
  • The pandemic accelerated one-to-one (or even two-to-one) device ratios. 
  • Prior to the pandemic and in early stages (even currently) few staff if any are responsible solely for educational technology.
  • Heavy reliance on TOSAs (teacher on special assignment) for EdTech responsibilities in many K-12 school districts.
  • Teacher use of ?free? programs to benefit student learning may pose privacy risk(s).
  • Technology as a quick fix to educational issues.
  • RFPs (request for proposals) focus on cost and usability rather than privacy/security Pandemic crisis response hastened K-12 technology needs. 
  • Technology adoption leads to technology adaptation.
  • Filtering efforts by districts (controlling search and access) perceived as privacy protection measures.
  • Oversight (i.e personnel) and access differs in rural or urban school districts Paradox: Benefits to student learning with use of student personal information helps teachers, yet significant privacy costs with collecting and storing student personal information.
  • A privacy/security chasm exists between Information technology (IT) and Educational technology (EdTech).
  • Resource allocation by school districts enables or limits access to technology Convenience drives school district technology adoption.
  • IT and EdTech personnel priorities differ.
    Cybersecurity is a proxy for K-12 privacy protection.

Key Recommendations: 

  • Prioritize student privacy.
  • Focus on Digital Data Literacy in K-12.
  • Offer and clarify data exchanges in digital literacy training for students, teachers, staff, and parents.
  • Improve transparency of profits associated with student?s personal information Privacy liaison (Privacy Manager) between IT and EdTech at school district level (at least).
  • Improve accountability by adding prompts about privacy specifically to state K-12 mandatory reporting.
  • Require technology funding details in state K-12 mandatory reporting.
  • Enforce and create stringent policies for EdTech procurement that differ from technology infrastructure decisions.
  • Carefully weigh protection of data with collection of student personal information.

We recommend addressing the privacy challenges we uncovered in our research by including question(s) and variables to overtly plan for privacy/security measures, coordination efforts between IT and EdTech (assisted and mediated by a privacy manager), and reporting actual expenses associated with and privacy and security action(s). This supports research and discussions among IT and communications technology professionals who have already stressed ?privacy-by- design? and building security into programs before they are created, rather than using encryption to protect data after the fact [2]. Again, this would set expectations for a focus on privacy/security and allow for better accountability. 

References:

[1] Ng, Wan. 2012. Can We Teach Digital Natives Digital Literacy? Computers and Education, 59 (3): 1065-1078. 

[2] Dragoni, Nicola, Alberto L. Lafuente, Fabio Massacci, and Anders Schlichtkrull. 2021. Are We Preparing Students to Build Security In? A Survey of European Cybersecurity in Higher Education Programs. IEEE Security and Privacy, 19 (1), 81-88.
